asw_1: Not insisting on your rights
asw_2: Allowing for other people's mistakes
asw_3: Stopping as a precaution at every crossroads
info:
Participation in road traffic requires constant caution and mutual respect. Therefore, defensive drivers expect other road users to make mistakes.

In addition, defensive drivers are prepared not to insist on their rights in order to resolve dangerous situations.
text: What should you understand by defensive driving?

asw_1: Unexpectedly heavy braking
asw_2: Inattentiveness
asw_3: Driving too close behind the vehicle in front
info:
Inattentiveness leads to reactions of other road users being recognized late or not at all. A lack of space between cars shortens the time available to react to the behaviour of the vehicle in front of you.

As a rule, the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you must be such that it can be retained even if the vehicle in front of you brakes suddenly.

If you are driving in front of other vehicles you must not brake hard without a compelling reason.
text: What can be the causes of rear-end collisions?

asw_1: - could brake unexpectedly
asw_2: - may switch on the direction indicators too late before turning
asw_3: - could stop unexpectedly to ask the way
info:
Due to the fact that the number plate is not local, it cannot be ruled out that the driver of the vehicle with the non-local number plate may not have any local knowledge and as a result may make unexpected decisions.

It is possible that the driver of the vehicle with the non-local number plate will brake unexpectedly. He or she could be very late in activating the direction indicators. The vehicle could also stop unexpectedly.
text: You are driving in a built-up area behind a vehicle with number plates that are not local. What could happen?

asw_1: Stalling the engine in dense traffic
asw_2: Vehicles proceeding too slowly for no good reason
asw_3: Motor vehicles breaking down because they have run out of fuel
info:
Anyone taking part in traffic must behave in such a way that no one else is harmed, endangered or harassed unnecessarily under the circumstances.

Motor vehicles must not drive so slowly that they impede the flow of traffic without good reason. A fuel shortage can be avoided by regularly checking the tank level.

Stalling the engine can be avoided by practicing starting.
text: What can cause unnecessary obstructions?

asw_1: Because it obstructs the flow of traffic
asw_2: Because it increases the danger of rear-end collisions
asw_3: Because it encourages vehicle drivers behind to overtake dangerously
info: Motor vehicles must not drive so slowly that they impede the flow of traffic without good reason. Slow driving increases the risk of rear-end collisions. In addition, it can tempt the driver of the vehicle behind you to overtake your vehicle.
text: Why must you not drive extra slowly for no good reason?

asw_1: Heavy eyelids
asw_2: Frequent yawning
asw_3: Quicker reaction time
info: Both heavy eyelids and frequent yawning are typical signs of fatigue. As a result of fatigue, the ability to react can be impaired, increasing the risk of accidents.
text: How can you tell that you are getting tired while you are driving?

asw_1: Microsleep
asw_2: Lack of concentration
asw_3: Driving mistakes
info:
There are many ways in which fatigue has a negative effect on the driver. There is a danger that he or she will fall asleep for a few seconds and thus lose control of his or her vehicle.

There is also a risk of a lack of concentration, which can lead to driving errors.
text: What can happen if you ignore signs of tiredness?

asw_1: Take a break straightaway
asw_2: Get out of the car and move around in the fresh air
asw_3: Listen to stimulating music
info: Taking breaks help the body to regenerate and can thus help combat fatigue. Exercise in fresh air stimulates the circulation and activates vital functions.
text: What should you do if you start feeling tired while driving?

asw_1: Decreases alertness
asw_2: Limits awareness
asw_3: Delays reactions
info: Fatigue can affect the driver in many ways. There is a risk of dwindling attention, limited perception of traffic events and delayed reactions.
text: How does tiredness affect your driving?

asw_1: Through vehicles at a standstill
asw_2: Through failure to maintain suitable speed
asw_3: By having lights turned on during day
info:
Whether the speed is too high or too low, in both cases there is a risk of dangerous traffic situations. For example, a low speed can motivate other motorists to overtake your vehicle in a dangerous manner.

Driving at too high a speed presents dangers such as leaving too little time to detect dangerous situations.

Depending on their position, vehicles at a standstill are only recognised by other motorists at a late stage, which can lead to collisions or dangerous evasive manoeuvres.
text: How could a dangerous situation arise?

asw_1: Distraction
asw_2: Inattention
asw_3: Tiredness
info:
Both distraction and inattention result in inadequate observation of the road and the traffic situation, presenting the threat of veering off the road. Fatigue presents the same danger.

Perception and reaction can be restricted, and there is also the threat of nodding off for a moment.
text: What could cause the vehicle to leave the road?

asw_1: They will run onto the zebra crossing without paying attention to traffic
asw_2: They will turn around on the zebra crossing for no apparent reason and run back
asw_3: They will wait at the curb because they always correctly judge the speed and distance of approaching vehicles
info: It is not certain that children will wait until a car stops at the zebra crossing. Instead, they may run across the street at any time. There is also the risk that they might spontaneously turn around on the zebra crossing and run back to where they came from.
text: What conduct must you expect of children at zebra crossings?

asw_1: - will already start running when the traffic lights in my driving direction change from green to amber
asw_2: - will also start running when the light is red because they cannot wait since it's taking them too long
asw_3: - will push each other onto the roadway
info:
The behaviour of children at a traffic light is difficult to predict. There is a risk that they will already start running across the road while the light is still red because, for example, they may overlook approaching vehicles.

They could also start running at the first sign of a change of traffic light. It is also possible that children may push each other into the road.
text: What do you have to reckon with when children are waiting at traffic lights?

asw_1: - will move onto the roadway without paying attention
asw_2: - will move too far onto the roadway
asw_3: - will get off their bicycles and wait until the roadway is clear
info:
As soon as a cycle path ends, there is always a risk that cyclists will move onto the road without interruption and continue their journey.

Children riding bicycles may not know or may disobey traffic rules and move into the lane in pairs or ride next to one another.
text: A group of children are cycling on a cycle path that ends. What do you have to reckon with?

asw_1: You may pass on the right-hand side at walking speed provided that passengers are not obstructed and you are sure no-one is endangered
asw_2: If no-one is obstructed or endangered, you may pass on the right-hand side at a speed faster than walking speed
asw_3: Passengers must allow moving traffic to pass before boarding
info: Scheduled buses, trams and marked school buses stopping at bus stops may only be overtaken carefully, even if they are oncoming traffic.
text: Which statements are correct?<pcaption>(Brake lights on)</pcaption>

asw_1: - not overtake the bus while it is still moving
asw_2: - pass the stationary bus at walking speed provided you are sure that passengers are not endangered
asw_3: - overtake the bus while it is still moving
info:
Scheduled buses and marked school buses approaching a bus stop and with hazard warning lights switched on may not be overtaken.

Scheduled buses and marked school buses stopped at bus stops with hazard warning lights turned on may only be overtaken at walking speed and at such a distance that passengers are not endangered.

Walking speed also applies to oncoming traffic on the same road. Bus passengers must not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
text: What must you heed in this situation?<pcaption>(Hazard warning lights on)</pcaption>

asw_1: They may stop on the road
asw_2: They may turn round and go back
asw_3: They will cross the road slowly
info: Crossing the road can be exhausting for elderly people with walking aids. Therefore, it cannot be excluded that they may cross the road slowly or even stop in the middle of the road. They may also turn back at any time due to uncertainty or for other reasons.
text: What do you have to reckon with when elderly persons using walking frames cross the road?

asw_1: I follow behind the wheelchair until I can overtake it
asw_2: I overtake it, leaving plenty of room on the side because the wheelchair may swing out
asw_3: I honk the horn to indicate that the person is not behaving correctly
info: Even if the person in the wheelchair does not behave in accordance with traffic regulations, caution and consideration are required. Therefore, overtaking is only allowed when a safe possibility arises. Because there is the possibility that a wheelchair user may swerve, overtaking must be carried out at an appropriate lateral distance.
text: A person in a wheelchair is travelling along the road although there is a pavement on the right. What do you do?

asw_1: I stop and switch on the hazard warning lights
asw_2: I get out of the car and help the person in the wheelchair
asw_3: I honk the horn and drive around the person
info: Due to the unfortunate situation, both the person in the wheelchair and other people may be endangered. This is why you should help the person. By switching on your hazard warning lights, other motorists are warned of the potentially dangerous situation.
text: Having crossed the road, a person in a wheelchair cannot get up the curb and onto the pavement. What do you do?

asw_1: The man
asw_2: The child
asw_3: The woman
info: The white stick indicates that the person is visually impaired. Upon closer inspection, the yellow armband confirms this.
text: Who has a severe visual handicap?

asw_1: watch out for children
asw_2: be ready to brake
asw_3: continue driving at the same speed
info: Although the children are not on the road, this could change quickly. It is thus crucial to keep an eye on the children and to be ready to brake.
text: How do you behave?

asw_1: the children will not get off the road in time
asw_2: some children will turn around again
asw_3: all children will wait on the pavement
info: The children are playing and may not notice the vehicle in time. Even after they have left the road, it is possible that one or more children could turn back to get the ball.
text: What risks must you be aware of?

asw_1: slow to walking pace
asw_2: remain ready to brake
asw_3: continue driving at same speed
info: It is not certain whether the children have noticed the traffic and will behave appropriately. Therefore, you must reduce your speed and be ready to brake.
text: How should you behave?

asw_1: slow to walking pace immediately
asw_2: remain ready to brake
asw_3: drive past at the same speed
info: Although nobody can be seen, a child could inattentively cross the road to get the ball at any time. Therefore, you must reduce your speed and be ready to brake.
text: How must you behave?

asw_1: - pass at walking speed only
asw_2: - pass only if you are sure that passengers are not endangered
asw_3: - not pass under any circumstances
info:
Scheduled buses and marked school buses stopped at bus stops with hazard warning lights turned on may only be overtaken at walking speed and at such a distance that passengers are not endangered.

Walking speed also applies to oncoming traffic on the same road. Bus passengers must not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
text: What must you heed in this situation?<pcaption>(Hazard warning lights on)</pcaption>

asw_1: The bus may be passed in either lane but no faster than at walking speed
asw_2: Vehicles in both lanes must stop if passengers would otherwise be endangered
asw_3: The vehicles in the left lane may pass the bus without paying any special attention
info:
Scheduled buses and marked school buses stopped at bus stops with hazard warning lights turned on may only be overtaken at walking speed and at such a distance that passengers are not endangered.

Walking speed also applies to oncoming traffic on the same road. Bus passengers must not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
text: Which statements are correct in this situation?<pcaption>(Hazard warning lights on)</pcaption>

asw_1: Slow down and be ready to brake
asw_2: Continue driving as before so as not to impede the traffic behind you
asw_3: Sound your horn and continue driving
info: A child could enter the road at any time without keeping an eye on the traffic. Therefore, you must reduce your speed and be ready to brake.
text: You are approaching children playing on the pavement. How must you behave?

asw_1: - may not be endangered
asw_2: - may not be impeded
asw_3: - may be warned using the horn
info:
Scheduled buses, trams and marked school buses stopping at bus stops may only be overtaken carefully, even if they are oncoming traffic.

When passengers are boarding or disembarking, they may only be passed on the right at walking speed and only at such a distance that there is no danger to passengers.

They must not be obstructed either. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
text: The tram has just become stationary at the stop. What is the right course of action?

asw_1: Near construction sites
asw_2: At junctions with farm tracks
asw_3: At innercity crossroads
info:
Agricultural machinery can discharge soil, clay and other dirt particles onto the roadway, which is why there is an increased risk of slipping at the junctions of dirt roads.

The same applies to junctions of construction sites. There is a risk of pollution from construction site traffic.
text: Where must you particularly reckon with dirt on the roadway and therefore danger of skidding?

asw_1: The contact between the tyres and the roadway deteriorates
asw_2: Wheel-spray can impair visibility
asw_3: Braking distances are greater
info:
Moisture increases the risk of road traffic accidents in many ways. Vehicles in front can splash water, which impairs visibility.

The moisture between the road surface and the tyres reduces the grip of the tyres, which results in a longer braking distance.
text: Why must the safe distance maintained be much greater on a wet roadway than on a dry roadway?

asw_1: On bridges
asw_2: On stretches of road running through forest
asw_3: On frequently used stretches of road
info:
Wind and a lack of subsoil cause the road surface on bridges to cool down more quickly, threatening earlier icing of the road.

The same applies to forests, where humidity is often higher and less or no direct sunlight reaches the roadway.
text: Where must you especially reckon with ice on the roadway?

asw_1: The road surface is uneven and road grip varies
asw_2: A tram might come from the opposite direction
asw_3: Driving on the tracks is dangerous
info:
Different road surfaces can have different grip and thus influence the driving stability. Especially on tracks, there is a risk of poorer traction. Cyclists must be particularly careful when crossing the tracks so that they do not lose traction.

At the same time, the tracks mean that a tram can appear from either direction at any time. In particular, motorists about to turn left must keep a close eye on rail traffic.
text: Why does driving on this stretch of road require greater alertness on the part of the motorist?

asw_1: Accelerating
asw_2: Braking
asw_3: Steering wheel movements
info:
On icy road sections, grip is reduced. Steering movements, braking and acceleration threaten the driving stability of the vehicle.

As soon as the road surface is no longer icy, such interventions can have an abrupt effect and thus significantly change the behaviour of the vehicle.
text: The road is icy for a short distance. What should you avoid here, if possible?

asw_1: By carefully applying the brakes at very low speed
asw_2: By jerking the steering wheel to the left and right
asw_3: By rapid acceleration
info:
If a road is suspected to be icy, a test should always be carried out with extreme caution to prevent the vehicle from swerving or skidding.

For this purpose, it is possible to brake in a controlled manner at a slow speed after looking into the rear-view mirror.
text: While driving, how can you safely check whether the road is icy?

asw_1: Because the roadway is slippery
asw_2: Because the view is obscured by the bend
asw_3: Because the roadway is made narrower by the wrongly parked car
info:
The incorrectly parked car makes it difficult to see into and around the bend. In addition, it requires a lane change while driving through a narrow lane at the same time.

The snow provides less grip, which makes steering more difficult and increases braking distance.
text: Why must you drive with particular caution here?

asw_1: Near rivers
asw_2: In marshy areas
asw_3: Near lakes
info: The sudden appearance of fog is possible almost everywhere. But in places near bodies of water, such as rivers, moors and lakes, the probability for fog to appear is particularly high.
text: Where must you be prepared to encounter sudden fog?

asw_1: Adapt your speed in time to visibility conditions
asw_2: Increase the distance from the vehicle in front
asw_3: Drive up close to the vehicle in front so you can use its rear lights as an orientation point
info:
In difficult visibility conditions, sources of danger are identified later than in normal visibility conditions. It is thus necessary to reduce your speed in order to adapt to the new visibility conditions.

If visibility due to fog, snow or rain is less than 50 m, the speed must not exceed 50 km/h unless a lower speed is required. Your vehicle may only be driven at such a speed that it can be stopped within a clear distance.

The distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you should be adjusted so that your vehicle can stop in time.
text: What do you do if visibility is drastically reduced by fog?

asw_1: Because it is not clear which direction the road will take
asw_2: Because the road surface is uneven
asw_3: Because oncoming traffic could cut the corner
info:
The combination of curve and dense vegetation at the edge of the road makes the course of the road unclear. At the same time, the bend is elongated, which increases the risk of oncoming traffic driving in the middle.

Cobblestones and repaired areas form an uneven road surface, which has different effects on the grip of the tyres.
text: Why do you have to pay particular attention here?

asw_1: Look to the right-hand edge of the roadway
asw_2: If necessary, reduce your speed
asw_3: Accelerate to get out of the beam of light more quickly
info: When oncoming traffic is dazzling, do not look directly into the headlights, but turn away your gaze and look as far as possible to the right side of the road. To reduce the risk of a collision due to dazzling traffic, reduce your speed if necessary.
text: What must you do in this situation when you are dazzled?

asw_1: That your vehicle will not be seen in time
asw_2: That you only detect oncoming vehicles after it is too late
asw_3: That the traffic lights are hardly distinct from the coloured signs
info: The colourful neon sign can lead to other motorists seeing your vehicle late. It may be more difficult to detect oncoming vehicles on time. The lights of traffic lights may not be recognized in a timely manner.
text: What must you be aware of here?

asw_1: At crossroads and junctions
asw_2: At pedestrian crossings
asw_3: On bends
info:
In curves, extreme centrifugal forces can act at high speeds, which can result in a loss of vehicle control.

At intersections and junctions, high speed can result in long braking distances.

There is a risk that crossing pedestrians will be detected too late at pedestrian crossings.
text: Where does driving fast often lead to accidents?

asw_1: At blind corners
asw_2: At road narrowings
asw_3: At level crossings
info:
At road narrowings, too high a speed could lead to a collision with oncoming traffic because the braking distance is too long. At level crossings, there is an increased risk of skidding due to tracks and possibly uneven road surfaces.

In blind corners, driving too fast can result in other motorists being seen too late.
text: Where is fast driving particularly dangerous?

asw_1: Reduce speed before reaching the bend
asw_2: Only accelerate again when the road straightens out
asw_3: Reduce speed only when you reach the centre of the bend
info:
At tight bends the speed should not be reduced only within the bend, but already beforehand. If you brake hard in a bend, the vehicle could swerve.

The same applies to acceleration in the curve, which is why you should only accelerate at the transition to a straight part of the road.
text: How do you take tight bends?

asw_1: Yes, because the truck and trailer can obscure the view of important traffic signs
asw_2: Yes, because the truck and trailer can obscure the view of the crossing traffic
asw_3: No, because trucks and trailers mostly drive at low speed
info: Overtaking is not permitted if the traffic situation is unclear. The truck obscures the view of crossing traffic as well as traffic signs.
text: Is it irresponsible to overtake a truck and trailer a short distance before a crossroads?

asw_1: - suddenly accelerates
asw_2: - swerves out to overtake
asw_3: - reduces his speed considerably
asw_pretext: When the road user being overtaken
info: Anyone who is being overtaken must not increase the speed of his or her vehicle. This would prolong the overtaking distance of the other vehicle and lead to unnecessary danger. Other hazards, such as pulling out, are also not permitted.
text: When are you in danger when overtaking?

asw_1: When the road user being overtaken suddenly accelerates
asw_2: When there is danger from unexpected oncoming traffic
asw_3: When the road user being overtaken considerably reduces his speed
info:
If the person caught up with suddenly accelerates, the overtaking procedure must be stopped. The overtaking manoeuvre must also be stopped in the event of sudden oncoming traffic.

Overtaking is only allowed if you can ensure that any oncoming traffic will not be obstructed during the entire time that you are overtaking. Furthermore, overtaking is only allowed if the driver is driving at a significantly higher speed than the person who is to be overtaken.

Anyone who is overtaken must not increase his or her speed.
text: In which cases must you abandon overtaking?

asw_1: If you are unable to drive considerably faster than the road user being overtaken
asw_2: If you do not have a clear view of the road ahead
asw_3: If the traffic situation is not clear
info:
Overtaking is only allowed if you can ensure that any oncoming traffic will not be obstructed during the entire time that you are overtaking.

Furthermore, overtaking is only allowed if the driver is driving at a significantly higher speed than the person to be overtaken.

Overtaking is not permitted if the traffic situation is unclear.
text: When is overtaking forbidden?

asw_1: - reduce speed drastically
asw_2: - swing out to the left before turning
asw_3: - move well over to the right
info: Due to the higher centre of gravity and a load that may be present, lorries often have to reduce their speed significantly before entering a curve. Depending on the length, the lorry may need to veer out.
text: What must you be prepared for when a truck in front of you wishes to turn right into a narrow street?

asw_1: Intersecting roads may have priority even though they are narrow and less well developed
asw_2: A better developed road always has priority
asw_3: The rule "right before left" applies without exception at all crossroads and junctions
info: Priority rules are not determined by the length or width of the road.
text: What do you have to particularly remember at crossroads and junctions in a built-up area?

asw_1: Because there is an increased danger of skidding when braking
asw_2: Because a vehicle could come from the right
asw_3: Because the car coming from the left has priority
info: The leaves cover the roadway, making it difficult to see vehicles on the road coming from the right. A vehicle could approach from the right, and since there are no right-of-way signs, 'right-before-left' applies. Moisture and leaves can impair traction and thus increase braking distance.
text: Why must you be particularly careful here?

asw_1: - rush onto the road without thinking
asw_2: - ride their bicycles onto the road without paying attention
asw_3: - always conduct themselves properly on the road
info: Not all children behave in a roadworthy manner. They could suddenly run into the road. Likewise, they could carelessly enter the road on bicycles.
text: You are approaching a school. Children are leaving the school grounds. What must you reckon with?

asw_1: To vehicles which have broken down
asw_2: To school buses with children boarding or alighting
asw_3: To a traffic congestion
info: Any person operating a regular bus service or a marked school bus must switch on hazard warning lights when approaching a bus stop and while passengers are boarding or alighting, provided that the authority responsible for road transport has ordered such behaviour for certain bus stops in accordance with national law. Apart from stopping and towing vehicles, hazard lights may only be switched on by those who want to endanger others by their vehicle or warn others of dangers, for example when approaching a traffic jam or at particularly slow driving speeds on motorways and other fast-moving roads.
text: What do hazard warning lights draw your attention to?

asw_1: - will swing far out to the left when turning
asw_2: - will slow down drastically before turning
asw_3: - cannot swing out due to rear-wheel steering
info: Combine harvesters are vehicles with a very high centre of gravity. It is thus necessary for such vehicles to reduce their speed significantly before entering a bend. Due to the dimensions of the vehicle, it may be necessary for the combine harvester to make a wide turn.
text: A big combine harvester in front of you wishes to turn right. What is correct?

asw_1: Particularly when braking or turning, parts of the load can fall off
asw_2: The indicators may be concealed, making it difficult to see when the combination of vehicles wishes to turn off
asw_3: The braking distance of the combination of vehicles is particularly short because of its load
info: In the case of a laden trailer, it cannot be ruled out that the indicators or other lights may be covered by the load and thus not be visible. Centrifugal forces when turning or braking can cause parts of the load to come loose and fall onto the road from the trailer.
text: You are driving behind a farm vehicle with a trailer carrying a high load. What must you reckon with?

asw_1: Reduce speed
asw_2: Be ready to brake
asw_3: Continue driving as before
info: The tractor driver's view is restricted. The tractor could drive onto the road at any time. It is thus important to reduce your speed and be ready to brake.
text: What should you do in this situation?

asw_1: The mounted implement can swing out when the tractor turns off
asw_2: The rear lights may be heavily soiled or concealed, making direction signals difficult or impossible to see when they are on
asw_3: Farm tractors can always be overtaken safely due to their low speed
info: With agricultural vehicles there is always a risk of indicators or other lights becoming dirty and thus becoming hard to see. Attachments extend the vehicle and can swivel out accordingly when the vehicle is turning.
text: You wish to overtake a farm tractor with a mounted implement extending beyond its back. What must you remember?

asw_1: A vehicle may be stationary there
asw_2: There may be an oncoming vehicle on my side of the road
asw_3: There may be a slow moving vehicle on my side of the road
info: Visibility is restricted meaning that risks such as oncoming vehicles, slow-moving vehicles or stationary vehicles are only detected at a late stage.
text: What must you anticipate on the other side of this crest in the road?

asw_1: An uneven and dirty roadway
asw_2: Workers and construction equipment on the roadway
asw_3: Police regulating traffic
info: Due to the construction site, the road can be uneven and dirty. It cannot be ruled out that construction equipment may be on the carriageway. In addition, construction workers can enter the road at any time.
text: What must you be prepared for in this situation?

asw_1: - make sure there is no road user beside you on the right intending to go straight on
asw_2: - simply glance in the mirror to check that there is no cyclist behind you
asw_3: - concentrate fully on the turning manoeuvre because any cyclist has to wait anyway
info: Even vehicles turning right can cut into the lanes or paths of other motorists. Therefore, it is important to check that there is no one next to the vehicle who wishes to drive straight ahead.
text: You are waiting at a traffic light and want to turn right. What should you remember?

asw_1: Wild animals unexpectedly crossing the roadway
asw_2: An obstruction caused by an accident involving a wild animal
asw_3: There is no reason to expect accidents involving wild animals on new roads
info: Newly constructed roads in wooded areas pose an increased risk of wildlife crossing the road, as the roadway may run through animal paths. A vehicle in front may already have been involved in an accident, resulting in an obstacle on the road.
text: You are driving on a new road through a woodland area. What must you reckon with?

asw_1: There could be stragglers following the herd
asw_2: The herd may come back and cross the road again
asw_3: There is no reason to expect any more animals
info: Wild animals such as deer like to travel in groups, so there is a possibility that more animals could follow and cross the road. The behaviour of wild animals is unpredictable; they could turn around and run onto the road again.
text: Several deer run across the road in front of your vehicle. What must you reckon with?

asw_1: At dusk
asw_2: At dawn
asw_3: At noon
info: Wild animals can cross the road at any time. Animals are, however, mainly active at dawn as well as at twilight.
text: At which time of the day do you have to reckon with increased wild animals crossing?

asw_1: Soiled roadways
asw_2: Slow farm vehicles
asw_3: Excessively wide farm vehicles
info: In rural areas, road use by agricultural vehicles must be expected. Tractors and other agricultural vehicles are often comparatively slow. The vehicles can be oversized, which requires increased caution, especially when overtaking – if safe overtaking is possible at all. If a vehicle enters the road from a field or forest, the road may become dirty, which in turn can lead to a loss of grip.
text: Which dangers must you reckon with above all in rural areas?

asw_1: The tractor can carry large work equipment which is difficult to see
asw_2: Despite the headlights being switched on, it is not always possible to discern the width of the tractor
asw_3: 2 wide trailers can be attached to the tractor
info: In the case of agricultural vehicles and their attachments, lights cannot always be mounted at the outermost points. Therefore, the vehicles can be wider than the lighting suggests. Depending on the type of tractor, it may be possible to tow up to two trailers. Depending on the design, the trailer may be wider than the tractor. Attachments can be considerably wider than the tractor, but depending on the type of implement, this is not always immediately obvious – especially in the dark.
text: A farm tractor is approaching you at dawn with its headlights switched on. What must you reckon with?

asw_1: Drive with dipped headlights also during the day even in well lit tunnels
asw_2: Take off your sunglasses
asw_3: Switch fog headlamps on
info: Anyone driving a vehicle must use dipped headlights when passing through a tunnel. This also applies if the tunnel is well lit. Sunglasses must be taken off in anticipation of the lack of light inside of the tunnel. Otherwise the perception could be impaired by the sunglasses.
text: What must you observe when you enter a tunnel?

asw_1: Switch hazard warning lights on
asw_2: When traffic comes to a standstill, keep a safety distance of approximately 5 m to the car ahead
asw_3: Secure and leave vehicle immediately

asw_1: Fatigue

asw_1: - tyres

For example, slipperiness can significantly increase braking distance. The type of tyres and tread depth influence the braking distance.

info: Unless there are other restrictions, a maximum speed of 50 km/h applies to all motor vehicles in built-up areas.

info:
The average reaction time of a human being is 1 second. The distance covered by a vehicle in one second is therefore the "reaction distance".

The rule of thumb for the calculation is as follows:

Reaction distance = (speed / 10) x 3.

info: The braking distance is increased by the driving speed squared. Therefore, a doubling of the speed results in a quadrupling of the braking distance. The rule of thumb for stopping distance is as follows: (speed in km/h / 10) x (speed in km/h / 10) Stopping distance = (60/10) x (60/10) = 36 m.

info: The sign indicates the following mandatory direction: "limited stopping restriction". A person driving a vehicle may not stop on the road for more than three minutes, except when getting into or out of the vehicle or when loading or unloading. The additional sign excludes severely handicapped people with extraordinary walking disabilities, bilateral amelia or phokomelia (birth defects) or with comparable function restrictions as well as blind people. In each case, the handicapped person must be in possession of a special parking permit releasing him or her from the stop prohibition. The exemption only applies if the parking card is clearly legible.

asw_1: 600 litres
asw_2: 50 litres
asw_3: 1 litre
info: Engine oils and similar lubricants are hazardous to water. One drop can make approx. 600 litres of water undrinkable.
text: Your vehicle loses oil. How much drinking water can be polluted by a single drop of oil?

asw_1: Do not breath in any fuel fumes
asw_2: Do not refuel when the tank is full and the nozzle has switched off
asw_3: Fill up to the brim if possible
info: Do not inhale fuel vapours when refuelling. Do not refuel when the tank is full according to the nozzle as the fuel is cool and could expand.
text: What must you remember when refuelling?

asw_1: Decelerate in good time and use the momentum of the car when the next traffic light is on red
asw_2: Avoid unnecessary acceleration and unnecessary braking
asw_3: Always accelerate to the maximum when the traffic light changes to green
info: A proactive driving style contributes to low fuel consumption and is thus considered environmentally conscious. It helps to avoid unnecessary acceleration and braking.
text: How do you drive with consideration to the environment?

asw_1: Paying attention to the fuel consumption of a motor vehicle when buying it
asw_2: Contributing to a constant flow of traffic by thinking ahead and driving correspondingly
asw_3: Using public transport, a bicycle or walking, wherever possible
info: The consideration of fuel consumption when buying a car contributes to a reduced environmental impact. A proactive driving style reduces fuel consumption. The use of public transport relieves the burden on the environment.
text: What can help save fuel and reduce pollution?

asw_1: - driving short distances
asw_2: - driving at flat-out speed
asw_3: - driving in crowded city centres
info: Avoiding trips is good for the environment. This is particularly true for journeys to crowded cities, short journeys and full throttle journeys.
text: What can you do to help protect the environment?

asw_1: The radius of the bend
asw_2: Speed
asw_3: Headwind
info: The higher the speed in the curve, the higher the centrifugal force. The smaller the curve radius, the higher the centrifugal force.
text: What influences the degree of centrifugal force on bends?

asw_1: Faulty shock-absorbers
asw_2: Insufficient or uneven tyre pressure
asw_3: Load is too small
info: Defective shock absorbers can adversely affect the inclination of the vehicle and thus impair driving stability. This may cause skidding on bends. If the tyre pressure is too low or varies, this has an unfavourable effect on road grip and driving stability.
text: What can cause skidding on bends?

asw_1: Cutting corners
asw_2: Dipping your headlights too late
asw_3: Driving too far behind the vehicle in front
info: Cutting corners is dangerous because there is a risk of collision with oncoming traffic. Late dimming may dazzle oncoming traffic, which may cross the lane or leave the lane.
text: What can cause a dangerous situation?

asw_1: Blind people lose their orientation when they are near the car
asw_2: The driver’s attention is significantly impaired
asw_3: It makes it easier for blind people to recognise where the road is
info: Listening to loud music is a distraction that affects the driver's attention. Blind pedestrians can be disturbed in their orientation by the loud music.
text: What are the effects of listening to loud music - especially with an extremely loud bass volume - in the car?

asw_1: Motorists in front of you may suddenly pull out to overtake
asw_2: Even a slight, unexpected side wind can effect road stability
asw_3: If you have full beam switched on, vehicles travelling in front of you will not pull out to overtake
info: If you approach at a high speed, there is a risk that other motorists will not recognize your vehicle approaching in time. They may pull out to overtake before they see your vehicle approaching. The higher the speed, the greater the effect of crosswind on driving stability.
text: What must you reckon with when you are driving in the left-hand lane of an autobahn at high speed?

asw_1: A dangerous greasy film on the surface of the road
asw_2: Bad visibility through helmet visor or goggles
asw_3: Shorter braking distance
info: Rain after prolonged dry periods can create a greasy film on the road surface. If splash water reaches the helmet visor or safety goggles, there is a risk of considerably reduced visibility.
text: What must you reckon with when it starts raining after a longer period of dry weather?

asw_1: Because of the inclined position, the upper part of your body could be hit by oncoming traffic
asw_2: The motorcycle could catch the central line and slip from under you
asw_3: There is no danger as long as the tyres are new
info: When driving close to the centre line during a left turn, the body threatens to protrude into the lane of oncoming traffic. Driving on the road markings may result in poorer grip and the motorcycle may slip.
text: What can happen if you drive around a left-hand bend near the marked central line?

asw_1: Increased tendency for the brakes to lock
asw_2: Increased danger of falling
asw_3: Spinning and skidding of the rear wheel when accelerating
info: Cobblestone pavement does not offer particularly good traction, which deteriorates additionally in wet conditions. This means that there is a risk of increased blocking of the brakes. There is an increased risk of falling. In addition, the rear wheel can spin or slip when accelerating.
text: What are the dangers on wet cobblestones?

asw_1: Visibility through goggles or helmet visor gets considerably worse
asw_2: Road surface damage is less noticeable when the road is wet
asw_3: Visibility is further reduced by water sprayed up by other vehicles
info: Both rain and splash water can significantly impair visibility through visors and protective goggles. Road damages are often recognized later or are generally not as easily recognizable. The splash water from other vehicles also impairs visibility.
text: What should you particularly remember when it is raining?

asw_1: Tramlines should always be crossed at the widest angle possible
asw_2: There is always greater danger of falling on tramlines
asw_3: Tramlines should always be crossed at the narrowest angle possible
info: To prevent tyres from slipping or wedging, tramlines should preferably be crossed at a wide angle (preferably vertically). There is always an increased risk of slipping and thus falling on the rails of a tram.
text: What should you remember when there are tramlines in your lane?

asw_1: Oil on the roadway
asw_2: Lane markings
asw_3: The outside edge of the bend is higher than the inside
info: Oil on the road surface can significantly impair road grip and thus increase the risk of falls. When driving over road markings, there is also a risk of a deterioration in grip.
text: What can cause the danger of falling on bends?

asw_1: Manhole covers on the roadway
asw_2: Leaves on the roadway
asw_3: Sand on the roadway
info: Direct contact between the road surface and the tyres promises the best grip. Foliage and sand impair traction. Likewise, manhole covers can impair traction.
text: What can cause the danger of falling on bends?

asw_1: When travelling on cobblestones
asw_2: When it starts raining
asw_3: On a concrete roadway with good grip
info: As rain sets in, brake discs and pads become damp, changing their properties. In this case, brake carefully. The same is true when driving on cobblestones, because the grip on cobblestones is comparatively poor.
text: When must you apply the brakes with particular care?

asw_1: High speed
asw_2: Worn tyres
asw_3: Grooves in the roadway
info: Worn tyres have poor water displacement, which in turn can cause aquaplaning. Water accumulates in ruts, which increases the danger. The higher the speed, the worse the water is drained through the treads.
text: What can cause in aquaplaning (sliding on wet roads) on wet road surfaces?

asw_1: There is still slush on the overtaking lane
asw_2: Slush could be thrown up and impair visibility
asw_3: Because beneath the slush there could also be ice on the road
info: The overtaking lane is covered with slush, which can severely impair road grip. In addition, there is the danger that the road under the slush may still be icy. The vehicles to be overtaken can splash slush and water, which impairs visibility.
text: Why could overtaking be dangerous here?

asw_1: Steer against the wind
asw_2: Reduce speed
asw_3: Accelerate rapidly
info: In strong crosswinds, counter-steering helps to keep the vehicle on track. A reduction in speed helps to keep the vehicle under control despite strong side winds.
text: What must you do if your vehicle is caught by a strong side wind?

asw_1: Your vehicle could be blown to the left by the strong side wind
asw_2: When overtaking, your vehicle is pulling to the right when you enter the slipstream of the truck
asw_3: The vehicle travelling in front of you can be blown to the right
info: The wind vane signals a side wind from the right, so your car is pushed to the left. When driving into the slipstream of the truck, the crosswind no longer acts so strongly pulling the car to the right.
text: What must you reckon with here?

asw_1: Because braking distance is increased
asw_2: Because visibility is reduced
asw_3: Because aquaplaning (sliding on wet roads) can occur
info: Heavy rainfall impairs visibility and thus requires speed adjustment. At the same time, aquaplaning is a risk. The braking distance is extended by heavy moisture.
text: Why must you reduce your speed in heavy rain?

asw_1: Danger of sliding and skidding
asw_2: Changes in tyre noise
asw_3: Longer reaction distance
info: A deterioration in the condition of the road surface may result in skidding or slipping, e.g., due to potholes or reduced traction caused by the road surface. A bad road often causes tyres to produce loud noises.
text: What can be caused if the road surface suddenly becomes worse?

asw_1: Bends are often very narrow and blind
asw_2: The narrow and often cambered roadway requires special caution when there is oncoming traffic
asw_3: The trees provide protection from the sides
info: Rows of trees are a characteristic of avenues. These often result in tight bends and can impair visibility. The carriageway may be narrow and curved, which requires increased caution, especially in the case of oncoming traffic.
text: What are the special conditions when driving along tree-lined avenues?

asw_1: In dips in the roadway
asw_2: Where there are grooves in the roadway
asw_3: At level crossings
info: Water can collect in dips in the roadway, which can cause aquaplaning.
text: Where does aquaplaning (sliding on wet roads) occur particularly often?

asw_1: A dangerous greasy film on the surface of the road
asw_2: Bad visibility immediately upon switching the windscreen wipers on
asw_3: Shorter braking distance
info: Dust and other dirt particles on the windshield can form a greasy film, making visibility difficult. A similar film can also form on the road surface, which can lead to deterioration in grip.
text: What must you reckon with when it starts raining after a long period of dry weather?

asw_1: Because a greasy film may form which increases the braking distance
asw_2: Because visibility may become worse and the windscreen wipers do not immediately provide a clear field of vision
asw_3: Because the brakes react more quickly
info: In the case of rain, a lubricating film can form on the road surface, which worsens the road grip. Dust and other dirt particles on the windshield can form a greasy film, making visibility difficult.
text: It starts raining. Why must you immediately increase the safe distance?

asw_1: No, because it could represent a danger to oncoming traffic
asw_2: Yes, if fog headlamps and rear fog lamps are switched on
asw_3: Yes, because it reduces the risk of running off the road
info: Crossing the middle line may reduce the risk of getting off the road, but it increases the risk of collision with oncoming traffic. Therefore, it is not allowed to use the roadway in this manner.
text: You are driving in dense fog on a federal road (Bundesstraße) outside a built-up area. Are you allowed to drive in the middle of the road continuously straddling the broken white line?

asw_1: Adapt speed immediately to visibility conditions
asw_2: Switch on dipped headlights
asw_3: Only switch on parking lights
info: Your speed should be adapted in particular to road, traffic, visibility and weather conditions as well as to the personal abilities and characteristics of the vehicle and load. If visibility due to fog, snow or rain is less than 50 m, the speed must not exceed 50 km/h unless a lower speed is required. If fog suddenly appears and visibility deteriorates your speed must thus be adapted immediately to the new visibility conditions. Switching on the dipped beam is necessary in order to be seen more easily by other motorists.
text: What must you do on encountering sudden dense fog driving at daytime?

asw_1: Switch on the windscreen wipers from time to time when it is foggy
asw_2: When there is slush, switch on the windscreen wipers already before slush is thrown onto your windscreen by other vehicles
asw_3: When the windscreen is steamed up, switch the ventilator off and keep the windows closed
info: Over time, small drops of fog may accumulate on the windscreen and affect visibility. Using the windscreen wipers as required helps to maintain good visibility. Trucks in particular can splash large quantities of slush onto the windscreen, which immediately restricts the visibility of the road and traffic. Switching on the windscreen wipers beforehand prevents this risk.
text: How can you achieve sufficient visibility through the windscreen?

asw_1: Immediately dip your headlights
asw_2: Sound the horn and brake
asw_3: Proceed on full beam
info: If wild animals are dazzled by full beam, they often stop in the beam of light. Therefore, the high beams must be turned off immediately. Additional honking of the horn can draw the animal's attention to the approaching danger. In addition, the brakes must be applied to prevent a collision.
text: What must you do if wild animals suddenly appear in the full beam of your headlights?

asw_1: You can be dazzled by reflections on the wet road
asw_2: Your wet windscreen can result in your being dazzled
asw_3: You can avoid possible dazzle by switching on full beam
info: In the dark, a wet road can intensify the effect dazzing headlights. In addition, streaks on the windscreen are more visible in the dark and can significantly impair visibility.
text: You are driving on a country road in darkness and rain and encounter oncoming vehicles with dipped headlights. What must you remember?

asw_1: You lose your feel for speed
asw_2: Your powers of concentration diminish
asw_3: The feel for the right speed on bends grows
info: When driving at high speed for a longer period of time, the perception changes and motorists often underestimate the speed. Since fast driving requires a high degree of concentration, the ability to concentrate decreases over time.
text: You have been driving at high speed for some time. What effects can this have?

asw_1: You lose your feel for speed
asw_2: You drive too close to vehicles in front
asw_3: Your reactions improve
info: When driving at high speed for a longer period of time, the perception changes and motorists often underestimate the speed. Due to the influenced perception, motorists tend to drive close to the vehicles in front of them.
text: What can result from driving for a long time at high speed?

asw_1: Driving for a long time at high speed
asw_2: Driving on a good, wide road
asw_3: Loud engine and tyre noise
info: When the road is wide and well developed, speed is often considered to be too low. Prolonged driving at high speed has a similar effect.
text: What can lead to your dangerously underestimating your own speed?

asw_1: To estimate the lateral distance to the trees and oncoming traffic simultaneously
asw_2: It may be necessary to stop within half the visible distance when a wide vehicle is coming from the opposite direction
asw_3: Rapidly changing light conditions make it easier to estimate lateral distances
info: Avenues are bordered by trees and often have a narrow lane. This makes it all the more important to consider the lateral distance twice, i.e., to oncoming traffic and trees. If an oncoming vehicle is very wide, it may be necessary for your vehicle to stop in order for both vehicles to drive past each other safely.
text: What is especially important when choosing the speed for driving along tree-lined avenues with narrow roadways?

asw_1: Because you must reckon with others in the queue swinging out to overtake
asw_2: Because the distance needed to overtake might not be sufficient
asw_3: Because if you perhaps need to push back into the queue, this could lead to an accident
info: The last person in a convoy to overtake has to cover the longest overtaking distance and is thus in the lane of oncoming traffic for a particularly long time. At the same time, it is to be expected that other motorists will also leave the convoy. If it should be necessary to merge back into the original lane, an accident could occur.
text: Why can it be dangerous if you, as the last in a queue, immediately overtake as soon as the oncoming traffic is past?

asw_1: No, because there is no queue of vehicles in the left lane
asw_2: Yes, if you do not drive faster than 80 km/h
asw_3: Yes, because there is enough space to overtake
info: Vehicles must overtake on the left. There is no reason to overtake from the right, especially as there is no queue on the left.

asw_1: - the distance you need to overtake would be too great
asw_2: - the light-coloured car could pull out to overtake
asw_3: - you are not allowed to cross the broken line

asw_1: Watch if the truck and trailer remain on the hard shoulder
asw_2: Allow the truck and trailer to enter the roadway when it indicates left

text: You are approaching the vehicles in this picture. What do you do?

asw_1: It is suddenly hit by a gust of strong side wind
asw_2: A burst tyre
asw_3: Sudden headwind
info: Veering sideways is also possible on dry roads. A strong crosswind that suddenly occuring can cause this. If a tyre bursts, the driving stability is impaired and the vehicle can also veer sideways.
text: What could cause a fast travelling motor vehicle suddenly to veer sideways on a dry straight road?

asw_1: Watching the queue through the windows of the vehicles travelling in front
asw_2: Driving in a slightly staggered position in your own lane
asw_3: Keeping your hazard warning lights switched on when driving
info: Driving in a slightly staggered position within one's own lane helps to better understand the traffic situation and, for example, recognize dangerous situations earlier. The view through the windows of the preceding vehicles can be similarly useful.
text: What makes driving in a stream of vehicles easier?

asw_1: Throttle down, if necessary, steer against and brake cautiously
asw_2: Stop, if possible, on the hard shoulder, switch on hazard warning lights and place the warning triangle
asw_3: Immediately apply the brakes fully and move over onto the hard shoulder
info: The first step is to keep the vehicle under control and bring it slowly but surely to a standstill. If possible, do not stop on the roadway; rather, stop on the hard shoulder of the road.
text: One of your tyres bursts while you are travelling at high speed on an autobahn. What do you do?

asw_1: The vehicle in front changing lanes
asw_2: Denser traffic beyond the underpass
asw_3: The right-hand lane coming to an end
info: The left lane ends. Therefore, the car in front will change to the right lane. The merging of both lanes results in a densification of traffic.
text: What must you reckon with here?

asw_1: If possible, switch on hazard warning lights to warn vehicles following behind
asw_2: Drive as far as possible to the right in order to leave room for a channel on the left
asw_3: Drive as far as possible to the left in order to leave room for a channel on the right
info: By switching on the hazard warning light, other motorists are warned earlier, which reduces the risk of accidents. If the traffic on motorways and extra-urban roads is congested with at least two lanes for one direction, vehicles must form a free lane in the middle of the directional lane for the passage of police and auxiliary vehicles. In the case of lanes with three lanes for one direction, this free lane must be formed between the left lane and the middle lane.
text: A traffic jam is building up here. What is the correct procedure?

asw_1: - not have any beverages containing alcohol while on duty and while on stand-by duty
asw_2: - not start to drive while under the effect of alcohol
asw_3: - have beverages containing alcohol while on duty, as long as a blood alcohol standard of 0.3 per mille is not exceeded
text: What must you remember as bus driver on duty?

asw_1: You may not take any drugs or medicaments which impair your ability to drive while on duty or stand-by duty
asw_2: You may not start to drive when your ability to drive is impaired by drugs or medicaments
asw_3: You may take any drug for which no prescription is required, without having to fear that your ability to drive is impaired
text: What must you remember as bus driver on duty?

asw_1: By well-timed and sufficient stops for rests
asw_2: Gymnastic exercises during stops
asw_3: Drink coffee and make no stops
info: In the case of fatigue, only recovery helps. The body must be given an appropriately long break. Gymnastic exercises help to stimulate the circulation and activate the body as a whole.
text: How can fatigue be prevented on a long journey?

asw_1: Strong emotions (e.g. delight, annoyance, impatience)
asw_2: Animated conversation
asw_3: Engrossing programs on the car radio
info: Lively conversations – with passengers or on the telephone – attract attention and can contribute to the fact that insufficient attention is paid to road traffic. The same applies to listening to exciting programmes on the car radio or driving when impacted by strong emotions.
text: What can diminish alertness in road traffic?

asw_1: Telephoning
asw_2: Lighting a cigarette
asw_3: Nagging children on the backseats
info: Lighting a cigarette while driving requires more attention than is generally assumed. For this reason, it is a major distraction. Children whining can significantly reduce the driver's concentration, as can making a phone call while behind the wheel.
text: What strongly distracts you while you are driving?

asw_1: - towards the centre of the roadway
asw_2: - on the right-hand edge of the roadway
info: Since there is only one lane in each direction, you should position your vehicle towards the middle of the roadway without obstructing oncoming traffic.

asw_1: The middle lane

Therefore, the use of the middle lane is permitted in this case.

text: You are approaching a traffic light which has been "green" for some time. What do you do?

asw_1: Increase your alertness and, as a matter of precaution, increase your distance to the vehicle in front
asw_2: In case of a traffic jam, brake and switch on hazard warning lights
asw_3: In case of a traffic jam, move over onto the hard shoulder and proceed

text: What do you do when you see this traffic sign on an autobahn?

asw_1: Reduce speed before the bend
asw_2: Drive as far as possible over on the right-hand side
asw_3: Indicate left before the bend
info: The sign alerting of a potentially dangerous “Kurve” warns of an unexpected or tight bend. You must reduce your speed so that no excessive centrifugal forces occur in the bend. In addition, drive far to the right in order to prevent possible collisions with oncoming traffic.
text: What must you do when you see this traffic sign?

asw_1: Drive more slowly, watch out for wild animals
asw_2: Dip the headlights and brake when you see wild animals
asw_3: Do not avoid hitting wild animals if oncoming traffic would be endangered
info: The danger sign "Wildwechsel" warns of wild animals that may enter the road. It is necessary to adjust the speed to be ready to brake in order to stop the vehicle in time in an emergency. When sighting wild animals, you must dim your lights and slow down. You should not swerve in order to avoid the animal if this can be avoided, because collisions with oncoming traffic may occur.

asw_1: By forming car pools

info: Avoiding traffic peaks means avoiding "stop-and-go traffic" or frequent stopping and starting, thus reducing fuel consumption. Avoiding roads with regular traffic jams has the same effect. Carpooling results in fewer vehicles on the roads and thus relieves the burden on the environment.

info:
The maximum authorised speed, even in the most favourable circumstances outside of built-up areas, is 80 km/h for

(a) motor vehicles with a maximum authorised mass exceeding 3.5 tonnes but not exceeding 7.5 tonnes, excluding passenger cars;

(b) passenger cars with trailers,

(c) lorries and motor caravans, each up to a maximum authorised mass of 3.5 tonnes with trailers; and

(d) buses and coaches, with or without luggage trailers.

Because the truck is leaving the priority road and turning into another lane, it is likely that the truck will give way to the pedestrian.

It is also possible that the pedestrian will first let the truck pass and then cross the road.

The truck restricts visibility, which means that other vehicles on the road cannot be seen yet.
text: You want to turn right. What must you be prepared for?

asw_1: For persons crossing
asw_2: For visual obstacles
asw_3: For vehicle doors opening
info:
There are numerous pedestrians who could cross the road. The vehicles parked on both sides obstruct visibility, which means, for example, that pedestrians crossing the road can only be seen at a late stage.

Passengers could get out of the parked vehicles at any time and open the doors.
text: What must you be prepared for?

asw_1: That adults could walk onto the road
asw_2: That children could appear between the vehicles
asw_3: That it could be necessary to brake heavily
info:
Children could appear between the vehicles at any time - the traffic sign even explicitly warns of this danger. In addition to children, adults could also run onto the road.

Due to the densely parked vehicles, pedestrians and other motorists may only be visible at a late stage, so that heavy braking may be necessary at any time.
text: What should you anticipate?

asw_1: They frequently have poorer sight and hearing
asw_2: They frequently react more slowly and are less mobile
asw_3: They frequently misjudge the speed of vehicles
info:
Reactivity and sensory perception decrease with increasing age. This is why older pedestrians often react more slowly and are less mobile.

They often misjudge the speeds of vehicles. Likewise, they may not see or hear as well.
text: Why are older pedestrians at more risk than younger ones from road traffic?

asw_1: That children playing run onto the road
asw_2: That cyclists are inattentive
asw_3: That all adults obey the road traffic regulations
info:
In residential areas with little traffic, there is an increased probability that motorists will underestimate the risks.

Therefore, cyclists and other motorists may be inattentive.

It cannot be ruled out that children may be playing near the road and possibly enter it.
text: What must you be aware of in residential areas with low traffic volumes?

asw_1: They will look neither left nor right
asw_2: They will unexpectedly walk onto the road
asw_3: Sometimes they turn back half-way across
info:
The behaviour of pedestrians is difficult to predict. Unlike motorists, they can turn around much more easily halfway across the road.

Some pedestrians rely exclusively on their hearing; therefore, they look neither to the left nor to the right. Pedestrians can enter the road unexpectedly at any time.
text: What actions should you anticipate from persons at the pedestrian crossing?

asw_1: - reduce speed and stop if necessary
asw_2: - give a warning signal

info:
In underground car parks, pedestrians are often on the vehicle lanes. Despite the lighting, it can be relatively dark in an underground car park compared to the previous environment, so that the eyes have to get used to the new lighting conditions first.

Narrow entrances and exits are not uncommon in underground garages. Tyres can be damaged by contact with kerbs or walls.

asw_1: Pedestrians could cross the road

Scheduled buses and marked school buses stopped at bus stops with hazard warning lights turned on may only be overtaken at walking speed and at such a distance that passengers are not endangered.

Walking speed also applies to oncoming traffic on the same road. Bus passengers must not be obstructed. If necessary, anyone driving a vehicle must wait.
text: What must you be aware of?

asw_1: With the unsafe riding manner of the cyclist

The cyclist is also affected by the difficult conditions, which can result in unsafe riding.

The person overtaking has to move back to the right as soon as possible. Motorists must not obstruct the vehicle that is to be overtaken.
